comment: I assume this is Japanese Ainu;   coordinates of Hokkaido Ainu
I assume this is Sorani; add coordinates?
for Glottolog I assume it is High German because the dialects belong to distinct branches
I assume this is the local dialect of Persian rather than the NW Iranian language of Kashan
chose West as the largest branch, but not certain
coordinates of Ostfränkisch: roughly at the middle of the are of Modern Germanic
add coordinates to distinguish Kabardian and Circassian?
probably distinct from West Circassian (= Adyghe)
I assume this is Khowar, the language spoken in Chitral in Pakistan. For Glottolog I assume it’s southern Khowar, but this is preliminary
coordinates of Askiz (the Glottolog coordinates may be a mistake)
I assume this is Mandinka and not Manding in general
used macrolanguage because it’s not clear what exactly Abaev refers to
indicate the coordinates of Icelandic specifically
I assume Abaev cites Old Nubian
probably Occitan;   Abaev seems to call Franco-Provençal «фр. (прованс.)»
I assume that when Abaev cites Ossetic, he cites modern Ossetic
arbitrarily chose Eastern Panjabi for Glottolog
I assign this to Nuclear Pashto in Glottolog because Wanetsi is separate
may actually be a variety of Ishkashimi;   coordinates of Zebak district
coordinates of Rusyn (roughly at the centre of historical Slavic territory)

column11: Abaev used «лопар.» in the earlier volumes so these are viewed as distinct

comment: I assume this is SE Turkic
Unclear: Kipchak or Siberian? Coordinates of Bashkir, on the assumption that this refers to Kipchak
cited in Tomaschek, but I cannot find any trace of this dialect in the sources. Probably not Pamir but W. Iranian
